command: Mount-DiskImage -ImagePath "C:\Temp\archive.iso"; $iso=(Get-DiskImage "C:\Temp\archive.iso" | Get-Volume).DriveLetter; $usb=(Get-Volume | Where-Object {$_.DriveType -eq 'Removable'} | Select-Object -First 1 -ExpandProperty DriveLetter); Copy-Item "$iso:\" "$usb:\Backup" -Recurse -Force; Dismount-DiskImage -ImagePath "C:\Temp\archive.iso"
explanation: Mounts a local ISO, copies its contents to a USB drive, and dismounts, populating the removable media with exfil content via a local mount.
rationale_steps: Mount a local disk image to access packaged data.
Determine both ISO and USB drive letters.
Copy all ISO contents to the USB and then dismount.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Well-formed PowerShell with balanced quotes/braces, valid cmdlets and separators, and plausible parameter usage throughout.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It mounts an ISO, finds a removable drive, copies contents to it, and dismounts—consistent with T1052—though success may hinge on environment details like Get-DiskImage|Get-Volume behavior and the destination folder existing.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with proper syntax, balanced quotes and parentheses, appropriate semicolons as command separators, and valid cmdlet parameters.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command fully implements the T1052 technique by mounting an ISO image, identifying a removable drive, copying data to it (exfiltration over physical medium), and cleaning up by dismounting the image.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, uses valid PowerShell cmdlets and syntax, balanced parentheses and quotes, and correct command separators.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1052 by mounting a staged ISO (implying prepared data) and copying its contents directly to a removable USB drive, simulating exfiltration over a physical medium.
